Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation.
Lengthy, moderately bitter and alcoholic finish.
I enjoyed this brew! Not what I would consider a world-class effort, but very good nonetheless!

Nice looking beer with a lasting soft pillow-like head.  Light aroma reminds me of an empty glass of Strong Belgian Ale, light yeast and bread.  Alcohol is not overpowering.  Smooth, warm palate with a nice aftertaste.  Not a bad beer but not great and not worth $6 Cdn.  Too mild to be exotic and too ambitious to be a session.

pleasant malty aroma. Pours golden brown with a slight cloudiness and foamy head. Palate is thin, very slight malts. Alcohol is not well hidden, interferes with hops resulting in a confusing finish. A slightly above average beer but not worth searching out.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2004  Bottled. 
Amber colour. Hoppy nose, with tones of sweat. Fully flavoured, richly hoppy making it a bit salty. Notes of citrus. Chewy. Finishes salty.

Mild aroma, spicy, malty, with distinct ginger aroma.  Very carbonated and jumpy on the tongue, with an even balance of hop bitterness and roasted malts.  There is some sweetness hidden behind the hop bitter, and almost has a syrup-like sourness.
A bitter and dry beer. It is an example of a classic English ale. It is not my favourite style, but this beer is one of the better examples.
smooth nice light malt charactor, small hint of hops finnishes sweet and fizzy
Overpowering bitter dryness crushes wild honey and shy malt...Silky pollenated flowers sprinkled with watery chemicals...A cask feel is threatened by bubble-riding, simple megahops...
A long lasting soft head in a very hoppy ale with balanced sweetness and a deep long lasting aroma. Lots of flavors here, lingering in my mouth, making me satisfied and happy.
Bottled at the Grey Lodge in Phila. Good beer was expecting a little more however. Hint of malt flavor the got bitter in the finish.

Gorgeous pour. Thick creamy off-white head. Slightly hazy golden color. Spicy aroma with a hint of citrus. A bit on the tart side giving way to apple notes. Medium bodied. Low carbonation. Semi-sweet but with a dry, somewhat bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2003 Substantial white foamy head and golden color. Light hoppy aroma. 
Smooth medium body.
Flavor begins mildly sweet, changing to a somewhat dry and pleasantly bitter finish. Aftertaste lasts quite a while.
Very malty and full bodied, and that peculiar hoppiness that creates, to me, a signature Young's taste. Quite good.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: I'd probably rate this better if I could actually drink a whole bottle.  However, every time I have one, it finds a way to explode on me.
Looks great: Amber and fine lasting head. I couldn't detect any particular aroma. Exellent taste with a lot of malt.

Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized white head that lingers. It has a good hoppy aroma with a nice malt backbone. Medium body with medium carbonation, the flavor is good and hoppy up front, but then the malty sweetness takes over and dominates the finish with a nice fruitiness. Very nicely balanced between the hops and sweetly fruity malts, this is one of the better English strong ales I have had and the best offering I have had from Young's. Very nice.

It is amazing how a change in this beer's temperature can alter the taste.   At first pour the ice cold Special Ale had an almost cream ale aftertaste.   After a temperature rise of  ten degrees the beer took on a hardy mouthfeel.   I enjoyed the hop flavor combined with the malt sweetness.   This is an excellent English Strong Ale.

Pours with a beautiful amber body topped by a thick lasting head with a good amount of lace left on the glass.  Sweet lemony hop aroma with a good malty balance.  Sweet malty flavor with a strong lemony hop background and a sweet malty finish.  Medium to full bodied, relatively smooth and slightly oily.

I'm rarely impressed with bottled beer that has crossed the Atlantic and this beer is no different.  Bought in South London you will rarely find a bitter as inviting and satisfying with wonderful hops, malt and fruit with a wonderful mineraly aftertaste.  Many stumbling nights can be traced directly back to this beer. In  Vancouver, I've never purchased a representative that does not taste stale.  It makes me want to cry.
Only slightly hazy copper color. Slight spice/citrus, but mostly a nice hops taste.

Not impressed with the aroma.  Kind of dusty and stale smelling.  Looks great with copper color body and nice head.  Flavor is very nice indeed!  Big fruitiness up front followed by malts and a hop finish.  The more it taste it the more I like it.

Pours a copper body with a small lasting white head.  Aroma is toffee with sweet bread notes.  Flavour is sweet with notes of toffee and light spices.  Also some fruit flavour and yeasty taste.  Palate is very smooth with a bitter and citrus closing.  A very good ale.

Copper with a white head. Aroma is relatively sweet, with a bit of butteriness. Flavor is medium sweet, fruity, peachy. Is a touch of butter, but not too much. Some slight notes of toffee and chocolate. Medium bitterness. A well balanced beer, but nothing too exciting.

This hazy amber ale has a rich frothy head with some lacing. The nose is lightly honeyed with rich bready sweetness and a hint of spiciness (anis?). The palate is unique with black licorice (perhaps horehound) and a yeasty, honeyed background. The finish is lightly spicy with an afterthought of citrusy hops.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2004 Rerate Interesting aroma, reminds me of coconut tanning oil for some reason, also has hints of toffee.  Good bitter flavor, about the same as before also detect some toffee in there. Thick mouthfeel, alcohol hidden well, detect a bit in the finish however.   Original 3.5 Bottle has an odd aroma (stale feet) but the pour does not. Nice bourbon-like appearance with a thin head.  Flavor - odd combination of several things - spruce; malt - mixed together well.  Overall, a satisfying quaffer.

The aroma was very faint and disappointing.  Cidery, biscuity with a tangy hop finish. Citrus notes. Aftertaste gets buttery and the hop builds. Good soft water ale, and the finish builds.  I don't like Young's as good as Fullers or Sam Smiths, but this is pretty solid.  Good appearance, good homebrew bottle, good beer.

Although curiously lacking in aroma - I detected rusty iron and some grassiness, nonetheless, the flavor is rich, malty and has elements of honey and citrus. The color is a beautiful amber, head negligible, carbonation smooth and almost draught-like...nice mouthfeel. The best thing of all though is how this ale fills your mouth with spicy, herbal hoppiness English-style, the hops are present from start to finish but are elegant and well-integrated into the overall character of the beer. Heavy-handed NW U.S. brewers could learn a few things about sublety from this brew, IMHO, at least when they are trying to make an English style ale. Yeast adds a fruitiness and fullness as well. This is a fine English ale.

I really expected more from this, because I enjoyed the double chococalte stout from young's so much. This one is good, but it's missing a lot of body and a fullness of flavor that the best ales have in quantity.
Excellent nutty/caramel flavored maltiness with a well balanced citrus hop finish. Quite good.

Dark golden color with a white head.  Aroma is fresh with fruit overtones.  Taste is very refreshing, clean.  Slightly dry with some bitterness at end, no lingering aftertaste.  A very drinkable beer.

A light nutbrown/dark amber beer with a fine head. It has a nice sweet fruity aroma with notes of alcohol. The flavor is strong of a good malt blend - with a nice medium sweetness and a really nice bitterness, that lingers.
yeasty aroma, medium bodied, a tad sticky, metallic and toffee maltiness, seems more weak than strong after drinking so many American Strong ales

Clean, faint nose.  Metallic hints prevail over the subdues floral hints.  The bottle claims "A phenomenal amount of hops" I however, disagree whole-heartedly.  Then again, we're not talking about the west coast of America here, anyways, definite fuggle hoppiness.  An almost root beery/licorice/ sassafrass root taste.  good malt presence though.  Just not what I Expected.
Malty nose, strong alcohol content, malty with hints of caramel

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2003 Very good, very, very good.  Not hard to see why this is an award winner.  Great hoppy aroma, with bags of flavour and sweet hints of toffee.  A very well balanced and delightful beer.  Re-rate...(aged for 1 year.  Colour and appearance has not changed from the fresh example.  However the nose has increased in intensity.  Unaged is a little harsh but the aged bottle has developed a vanilla and toffee complex that is very pleasant.  The change in taste is fantastic, making a good ale a great ale.  Complexity has increased.  It is warmer with toffee and raisin flavours.  The development in flavour has made it more rounded and the difference between the two samples is surprisingly noticeable.

milennium edition;
Very much a pale ale.  Crisp, clear, and clean, well balanced, however it is extremely dry.  A little to dry for my tastes

Rerate: Millennium Edition: Light orange gold color. Medium head. Aroma is lightly malty, with a touch of caramel and toffee. Medium bodied English Strong Ale. Lightly malty and fairly hoppy. Light caramel flavor, a little spicy. Milder flavors, touches of fruit, caramel, butter, and toffee. Very drinkable, tasty beer.  Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. No noticeable alcohol bite at 6.4%. OLD RATING ------

Light brown color, small head. Lightly malty and fairly hoppy. Light carmel flavor, a little spicy. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Need to re-taste this beer. Beer number 10 in an 11 beer tasting night and taste buds were still jazzed from Ommegang Three Philosophers.
Medium brown color.  Lighter than I expected.  Rich flavour, heavily hopped, a little thinner than I expected.  Very cleansing.  Dry finish.

Dark golden colour. Good and interesting hoppy aroma. The various hops also dominate the flavour which is also lightly fruity and malty. Long, dry bitter finish. A good and interesting English ale, but nothing fantastic.

Bottle - Millennium Edition. Bright amber with a creamy head.  Fruity hops and dry malt aroma.  Malt creaminess throughout the quaff. Flavors of sharp hops (anise) and yeast flavors of light fruit, bananas and orange zest.  Peppery hops finish. Quite enjoyable.
Bottle.  Everything was just a little.  A little caramel, a little spice, a touch of vineous aroma and flavor, and a little offensive.
This is how I picture English beers to be. Love the Fuggles and Goldings. Wish all beers were this good.
Yeee-haw!  This is my kind of beer.  Sweet, hoppy, low carbonation.  A pleasure to drink.  Full bodied, very complex, wicked stuff.  My idea of english beer.
amber. Small bead. Flowery hop nose.Chewy Malt.Good hops throughout with long finish
A excellent brew. Creamy maltiness with a light fruity character and crisp hop bite.  Notes of clove and banana with a peppery punch of English hops.

The color is a brown orange mix with an off white fluffy  foam.  It smell of sweet malts, and a slight fresh hoppy smell along with a hint of toffee.  Taste is a little disapointing from what I expected but that did not diminish the enjoyment of this warming malty brew.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2005 I enjoy this now and then as I have for years and as I doubt my ability to add much that hasnt been said Ill say that the most interesting time was once getting some bottles past their "best before" date that tasted for all the wold like some bizarre Belgian lambic.
Full of malty body.  There are hints of toffee and winter fruits.  Hops dont really get a look in.  But this is still a warming beer that would be nice on a winter night.

Its very apparent after drinking this beer that the English have no idea about hops.  Hello?!?  How about a little hops!  Caramel flavors, tannin and earthy.  But the English have a lot to learn about full-bodied ales.  Maybe they should go to California and pick up some AleSmith or Stone brews.

A nice bright orange color with off-white, fully head.  The aroma was hoppy, but also slightly sour.  The flavors were nice--hops, sweet fruit, perhaps even a touch of spice.  Pleasant but not outstanding.

The aroma is rather weak with nothing remarkable to speak of, appearance is much the same, thin and pale. The taste starts hoppy but is soon overcame by creamy malt that is delicious. It leaves a somewhat bitter hoppy aftertaste that while good doesnt blend with the maltieness as well as it could. A good ale but not worth the price.

Like others experienced a lot of the contents was lost when the beer was opened. Might be because of the bottle conditioning. What do I know! Has a beautiful orange colour with a somewhat boring head. The aroma is wery fruity and malty. Has a nice bitter flavour, where the alcahol is dominant. In the aftertaste there is this great bitterness and I have notes of apples. Very pleasant acquaintance.

An orange peel flows into my nostrels as the off white foamy head diminishes. . .staring into the wonderful copper colour I am transported to an English pub where this colour of beer is more common and the bar keep just set my fish n chips basket on the bar and then slides the vineger down to me as he walks away. The creamy malt and lingering bitterness is a perfect match with my chips. . .I sigh and then my roommate hits me with a pillow and I realize that the TV is tuned to the soap opera network and I am staring dreamily at it. . .he doesnt understand that I was thinking about the beer and not paying attention to TV. . .

Pours with very little fizzy head. Deep amber. Nose of fresh hops. Very smooth on the palate in proper Ram fashion.The hops impart a spiciness and a bitterness in the after-taste over a strong bitterness on the palate. Very malty, very good for those who like full bodied ales without buying a stout or porter. Very enjoyable suds.

Kind of piney hoppy aroma, golden brown like the description says. This gets a little better as it warms, some of the toasty malt flavors come through which accompany the hops nicely. However this is not really a stand-out beer. Nothing special about it, just a pleasant moderately strong ale.
Millenium Edition: hoppy for a british beer, thin, spicy with light carmel complements. Very decent and probably good with subdued saucy meat dishes but its not a stand out.
Pear aroma. Full boedied. Malty, peppery flavor in which alcohol is clearly present. Licorice. Nice warming ale.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2005 Huge head overflow.  Had this with Marinaro500 and the loss was a tragedy.  From what we had left there was a bitter fruity taste with banana, pear, and apple.  Some spice in the middle.  Youngs is continuing to grow on me.
Update 12/25/05:  Still same feelings as above, but after much more sampling Id say the overall impression has lessened.  Still, the hop presence really took me back, and balanced out with some nice fruit flavors.

We lost 2/3rds of the bottle upon opening it!  It fountained out like children on the last day of school!  It went everywhere except into our glasses!  We were left with 2inches in our pint glasses and 4 inches of thick off-white head. I noticed the floaties in the puddle on the countertop.  The remaining ale was fruity and bitter. Silky smooth to drink! I will pick up some more to re-rate,but enjoyed the tiny bit I managed to catch .
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2004 Amber hue.  Sweet malt nose.  Awesome malts, banana, orange peel, medium bodied.  Hops come through in the end.  Decent brew from Young's.

Excellent beer! This must rank as the best Youngs beer ive had (close with double choc stout!).  Its strong without being overwhelming.  To me, its perfectly balanced, and finished with delightful toffee flavours.  It look so inviting, with its dark golden colour.

Clear, amber colored. Nice slightly off white head. Nose is malty, slightly citric, floral hops and more. Soft body, gentle carbonation, vinous mouthfeel, heady malt backbone with tons of hops, floral, perfumy and then bitter to finish it. Can definitley tell there were more then one kind used. A first rate english ale....
This is a good ale.  I recently shared a single with my brother and we both really enjoyed the flavor of this ale.  This is a nice surprise, much better than I anticipated
Great interplay between the hops bitterness and the malty sweetness. Full body. Nice golden color. Seems like a perfectly balanced ale.

Clear light copper body, with quickly dissipating off-white head.  Aroma dominated by caramel and toffee maltiness, with slight English hoppy aroma bringing up the rear.  Flavor is malty sweet, with decent amount of hoppiness -- still, sweetness is a bit much.  Chewy body.

Malty sweet, very slightly caramel aroma with some hoppiness.  Deep golden brown color.  Sweet flavor without much complexity, though there is some fruity sweetness in the beginning and some slightly bitter hoppiness in the end.
quite tasty. seems like belgian yeast. pretty fruity
2.5 years past its used by date. Peeeuuuke! Stinks like a cheap sherry depthcharged light beer shandy. Tastes like one too, but I cant hold that against it so Ill go for the average score.
A very high quality Ale with some very complex and wonderful flavor.  It is good on a cold winters day.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2003 I can see why this is one of the highest-rated Young's beers.  A quality ale with some complexity, and the alcohol is fairly well concealed.  A pleasure to drink.  Copper-colored, of course.  One of the best Young's brews.  My bottle was sort of murky yet deliciously mild and malty.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2005 Drinking this made me feel like I was eating panettone. Powerful fruity aroma with noticeable alcohol. Succulent buttery body - rich sultana, fig and date fruitiness - heaps of spicy hop character without overbalancing it in the bitterness dept. Tasty dry herbal aftertaste and a good alcohol kick. rer8: how is this an english strong ale and not an IPA i ask you. i like this more every time i have it - heaps of leafy, peppery hop flavour on a mellow, woody, fruity base, fullbodied but swillable, its what i think of when i think of a good IPA. rer8 2 years later: i still love  this beer, even though  the rest of youngss (where does that apostrophe go?) beers suck. warm maris otter, tasty mix of pawpaw esters and earthy, resinny hop flavour sitting on top, with a dry, minerally finish.
Light brown color, sweet roasted malt flavor.

I think this beer is a classic case of the whole being less that the sum of its parts. Theres some great grapefruit hops flavors and some nice sweet malt in here. However the flavors just never seem to mesh together. Dont get me wrong this isnt an unpleasant beer, it just never seems to come together in the end.
Goldend color with a medium white head.  Noticable alcohol content wich makes it a little sweet.  Nice hopps bitterness and overall a decent ale.
Nice bitterness but the alcohol makes it a bit too sweet for my liking.

Decent beer....not great....nothing from Youngs is as good as their chocolate.  Very good representation of the style....nice malt taste without too much punch in the finish....more hop prominience later would have helped.
Tested Bottled Conditioned. A Quality Strong Ale. A very nice hoppy bitterness, but the alcohol is somewhat over bearing of the flavours.
Nut brown. Big, nice, dry orangey hop aroma. Loads of chewy malt, very bitter finish. Yummy.
The malt in this is perfect.  Extra points for being an English beer, that has a good strong hops flavor.

A nice caramel color and very big-off white head.  I have had this a long time ago but didnt remember enjoying it as much as i did this time.  Really nice flavors from start to finish with a nice little bite at the end. I saw a comment from another rater about it being over-hopped, but being from the Pacific Northwest where hops are king i found it fairly easy to drink compared to some of the local IPAs.

Clear mid-gold colour with small thin light beige head. Faint fruity/floral hops and lesser malt aroma. Start is bright, fresh and medium bodied with maybe a touch of caramel, candy, chewing gum and whiskey thrown in. This beer has more of a classic bitter type flavour than I expected. The first time I tried this I remember it starting well but ending poorly but this time I found it quite refreshing, it must have been the great outdoors. 
(Rated 8/5/02: Laycock village tourist car park UK)
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2003 Amber color and really big head. Lots of flavors, but I don't recognize most of them. Strawberry and raisons, I think. Pretty unique and good
A big headed beer with little activity underneath.  A fruity tasting beer that is over hopped to be great.
Definitely apple taste and smell.  Somewhat spicy.  Handsome reddish-amber appearance.  Lingering carbonation and effervescence into the aftertaste, pretty nice!!
Smelled and tasted a lot like apples.  A little heavy on carbonation, but a good taste.
Nice bitter taste, marked hoppiness.

Had a bottle of this when I was grilling out today...Spring Is Here!!  This brew pours a
hazy/murky bottle conditioned orange amber.  The rocky/frothy off-white head is huge
and mostly lasting with fair lacing.  The nose is subtle and complex; mostly sweet and
spicy with hints of flowers, herbs, resin, cask wood, honey, ginger, clove, licorice, cola,
and alcohol.  The complex flowery, rich, warm,  flavor is somewhere between a
doppelbock and a Belgian strong ale.  The average to long finish is alcoholic with notes of
cask wood.  The light to medium dry/creamy body has lively carbonation.  Very nice.

Not bad but a 
disappointing beer.  Nice bitter start but left a vinegary taste in my mouth.  I will definitely try it again.
Wow.  A truely pleasant combination of IPA with mild.  A nice amber almost orange color, mild carbonation, stong bitterness, a little bit of toffee, it keeps you coming back for more.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2004 USA keg: Clear brownish amber appearance, decent head formation. Rich malty, fruity aroma. Sweet toffee/caramel malts, pretty hearty and robust, alcoholevident with a bitter citric bite that runs throughout. Somewhat of a cross between an ESB and an IPA. Top notch brew and a current personal favorite.
Nice bitter  carmel malt taste. Some tea flavors also. It gets much smoother as it warms.

Nice golden color and clean, hoppy aroma.  The taste is bitter as expected but not too much so by any means, and malty caramel notes make for a nice finish.  This gets even smoother when it warms a bit, with some sweetness and maybe even a little really hoppy citrus.  I would have thought the ABV to be higher than it is, mainly because of the warming effect. Overall, my favorite of this style and one I try to have whenever possible!
Lovely hop aroma, and deliciously bitter taste. Hints of burnt carmel on the palate. One of my favorite session(?) beers.
Cant really fault this beer on anything. Superb hoppy taste

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 500ml bottle.  Fruity, lightly hoppy aroma, with notes of orange citrus,  cedar, grainy, gently sweet and toasty pale malts along with a blend of faint herbal spiciness and doughy yeast in the background.  Hazy medium-dark amber color with a lasting, creamy, off-white head that generated some impressive lacing.  Flavor profile is well balanced throughout, with a blend of sweet, lightly honeyish, toasty and nutty malts combined with a moderate amount of fruity hop flavor that also contributes a spicy, herbal, almost tea-like quality and medium amount of bitterness.  Finish is surprisingly long and juicy with plenty of hop tones.  Creamy and smoothly effervescent on the palate with a medium body.  Quite flavorful and drinkable.
Kind of a bit sweet or something, quite bitter on the finish, but its to sticky.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2004 Bottle conditioned, BBE March 2004. Amber, Initial flurry of white head soon disappears, quite low condition. Good fruit and caramel nose with hints of malt and good level of hop aromas, adding the yeast sediment improves the appeal. Full but soft in the mouth with delicate peppery hops and fruity malt, some traces of cardboard around the edges. Lots of toffee and hop bitterness in the finish with traces of yeast lingering.
This beer makes me happy, untill the bottle is empty. Then I am sad.

Orange-red color, topped by a simply stunning thick-meringue head; nose full and flowery; flavor absolutely outstanding -- as many have commented, more hops than usual for an English ale, though still not a lot by USA standards-- but this is fine by me.  Caramel, orange flavors seem to dominate, but theres a lot going on.  Another winner from Youngs.
Not bad, just not for me.

A very nice bottle-conditioned ale. Chewy from the get-go and warming throughout. This is a filling beer with more hops then usual for the style like the other raters stated. Let it warm up a bit before you sink in.
Superb Ale, excellent stuff, the best bitter ive ever tasted :)

Claims to be an iPA but tastes more like a hoppy English bitter ale.
 very enjoyable. nice malt/hop balance
UPDATED: JUN 15, 2014 Perfumey, flowery hops and a hefty malt backing. If only all Youngs beers were this good AND bottle-conditioned.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Big chewy, juicy maltiness, with the biggest dash of hop bitterness Ive tasted in an English beer.  Nice beer.

Slight malt aroma.  Dark amber color.  Malt is subdued, not aggressive enough, which is okay for me.  But I export more with this type of British bitter/pale ale. Alcohol makes itself known after a few sips, along with bitterness. However, hop flavors are sadly missing. Certainly not an offensive brew, but I wouldnt go out of my way to try it again.
Its good, but I dont see the greatness.  The chewy malt and earthy hops just dont quite come together for me.  A lot of good flavours, but they seem to fight each other.

Remember what Poe wrote? Fill with mingled cream and amber,/I will drain that glass again. He probably had something like this in mind. It is as poetic as Poes best. The balance of malt, bitterness, hops, and caramel is wonderful.
It was good, but highly carbonated.  Be careful when opening this one.
Hoppy, but to me, right on the verge of being too hoppy, but being just right. A very nice beer.

Amber brown with a huge foamy
head that lasted quite awhile.
Slightly malty, but this beer
was as hopped as an American pale
ale.  Wow.  Alot of hop flavor.
A little on the buttery side.
amber colour, deep bitter, orange and nut aroma, complex flavor, great bitterness
